title: Beginning of Hadean Eon
description: Formation of Earth marked the beginning of the Hadean Eon, characterized by extreme heat, frequent asteroid impacts, and the gradual formation of Earth's first crust from molten rock.

title: End of Hadean Eon
description: The Hadean Eon ended as Earth's crust stabilized and the Late Heavy Bombardment concluded, transitioning into the Archean Eon when the first solid rocks and possible early life emerged.

title: Beginning of Archean Eon
description: The Archean Eon began with Earth's crust stabilizing and oceans forming. First stromatolites appeared, oxygen-producing cyanobacteria evolved, and the earliest continents started to form from volcanic activity.

title: End of Archean Eon
description: The Archean Eon concluded as oxygen levels rose significantly from photosynthetic organisms, continental masses grew larger, and Earth's atmosphere underwent the Great Oxidation Event preparation.

title: Beginning of Proterozoic Eon
description: The Proterozoic Eon began with the Great Oxidation Event transforming Earth's atmosphere. Eukaryotic cells evolved, continents formed stable cratons, and the first supercontinent Columbia assembled.

title: End of Proterozoic Eon
description: The Proterozoic Eon ended after the Ediacaran Period when complex multicellular life proliferated and the Cambrian explosion was imminent, marking the transition to the Phanerozoic Eon.

title: Beginning of Phanerozoic Eon
description: The Phanerozoic Eon began with the Cambrian explosion, a rapid diversification of multicellular life forms including the first animals with hard shells, complex eyes, and diverse body plans.

title: Beginning of Paleozoic Era
description: The Paleozoic Era started with the Cambrian Period's explosion of life, witnessing the evolution of fish, amphibians, insects, land plants, and the formation of the supercontinent Pangaea.

title: Beginning of Cambrian Period
description: The Cambrian Period began with an explosive diversification of life known as the Cambrian explosion. Trilobites, brachiopods, and the first vertebrates appeared in warm shallow seas.

title: End of Cambrian Period
description: The Cambrian Period ended with extinctions of many trilobite families and archaeocyathids, transitioning to the Ordovician Period as marine life continued diversifying and continents drifted.

title: Beginning of Ordovician Period
description: The Ordovician Period began with diversification of marine invertebrates, the first coral reefs, nautiloids dominating as predators, and the colonization of land by early plants and arthropods.

title: End of Ordovician Period
description: The Ordovician Period ended with the Ordovician-Silurian extinction events, caused by glaciation and sea level changes, eliminating about 85% of marine species including many brachiopods and trilobites.

title: Beginning of Silurian Period
description: The Silurian Period began after the ice age with recovering marine ecosystems. Vascular plants colonized land, jawed fish evolved, and the first millipedes and arachnids appeared on land.

title: End of Silurian Period
description: The Silurian Period concluded with minor extinction events and climate changes, transitioning to the Devonian as land plants developed more complex root systems and fish continued evolving.

title: Beginning of Devonian Period
description: The Devonian Period, known as the Age of Fishes, saw armored fish, sharks, and lobe-finned fish proliferate. First forests appeared, insects diversified, and tetrapods began land colonization.

title: End of Devonian Period
description: The Devonian Period ended with the Late Devonian extinction, eliminating many marine species especially reef-building organisms, caused by anoxic ocean conditions and climate fluctuations.

title: Beginning of Carboniferous Period
description: The Carboniferous Period began with vast swamp forests producing coal deposits. Giant insects evolved in oxygen-rich atmosphere, amphibians dominated wetlands, and first reptiles appeared.

title: End of Carboniferous Period
description: The Carboniferous Period ended as climate became drier, rainforests collapsed, and Pangaea's assembly completed. Reptiles adapted to drier conditions, replacing amphibians as dominant land vertebrates.

title: Beginning of Permian Period
description: The Permian Period began with Pangaea fully formed and arid climates expanding. Synapsids (mammal ancestors) dominated, therapsids evolved, and conifers spread across dry landscapes.

title: End of Permian Period
description: The Permian Period ended with Earth's largest mass extinction, the Great Dying, eliminating 96% of marine species and 70% of land vertebrates from massive volcanism and climate catastrophe.

title: End of Paleozoic Era
description: The Paleozoic Era concluded with the catastrophic Permian-Triassic extinction, clearing ecological niches for dinosaurs and mammals to evolve during the following Mesozoic Era.

title: Beginning of Mesozoic Era
description: The Mesozoic Era, Age of Reptiles, began after the Great Dying with Earth's ecosystems recovering. Dinosaurs would evolve and dominate, flowering plants appeared, and mammals remained small.

title: Beginning of Triassic Period
description: The Triassic Period began with sparse ecosystems recovering from extinction. First dinosaurs, pterosaurs, and marine reptiles evolved as Pangaea remained intact under hot dry climates.

title: End of Triassic Period
description: The Triassic Period ended with another major extinction event eliminating many archosaur groups and allowing dinosaurs to become dominant in the Jurassic, likely caused by volcanic activity.

title: Beginning of Jurassic Period
description: The Jurassic Period began with dinosaurs dominating terrestrial ecosystems. Sauropods reached enormous sizes, pterosaurs ruled skies, and first birds evolved from theropod dinosaurs.

title: End of Jurassic Period
description: The Jurassic Period concluded with minor extinctions as Pangaea continued fragmenting. Flowering plants began appearing, and ecological niches diversified entering the Cretaceous Period.

title: Beginning of Cretaceous Period
description: The Cretaceous Period began with dinosaurs at peak diversity. Flowering plants revolutionized ecosystems, Tyrannosaurus and Triceratops evolved, and seas teemed with mosasaurs and ammonites.

title: End of Cretaceous Period
description: The Cretaceous Period ended catastrophically when a massive asteroid struck Chicxulub, Mexico, causing global wildfires, tsunamis, and climate change that killed all non-avian dinosaurs.

title: End of Mesozoic Era
description: The Mesozoic Era ended with the Chicxulub asteroid impact, terminating the age of dinosaurs and opening ecological opportunities for mammals to diversify and eventually dominate.

title: Beginning of Cenozoic Era
description: The Cenozoic Era, Age of Mammals, began after dinosaurs' extinction. Mammals rapidly diversified into numerous forms, birds flourished, and flowering plants dominated terrestrial vegetation.

title: Beginning of Paleogene Period
description: The Paleogene Period began with mammals filling ecological niches left by dinosaurs. Primates, whales, and modern bird groups evolved during this time of recovery and diversification.

title: Beginning of Paleocene Epoch
description: The Paleocene Epoch began immediately after the asteroid impact with sparse ecosystems. Small mammals diversified rapidly, early primates appeared, and forests recovered from devastation.

title: End of Paleocene Epoch
description: The Paleocene Epoch ended with the Paleocene-Eocene Thermal Maximum, a rapid global warming event that dramatically altered ecosystems and led to further mammalian diversification.

title: Beginning of Eocene Epoch
description: The Eocene Epoch began during peak global warmth with tropical forests near poles. Modern mammal orders emerged including horses, bats, whales transitioning to ocean life.

title: End of Eocene Epoch
description: The Eocene Epoch ended with global cooling and the Grande Coupure extinction in Europe. Ice sheets formed in Antarctica, and tropical forests retreated toward the equator.

title: Beginning of Oligocene Epoch
description: The Oligocene Epoch began with cooler climates and grasslands spreading. Large mammals evolved, including early elephants, rhinoceroses, and cats, while Antarctica became fully glaciated.

title: End of Oligocene Epoch
description: The Oligocene Epoch concluded with continued cooling and drying trends. Grasslands expanded further, setting the stage for the evolution of grazing mammals in the Miocene.

title: End of Paleogene Period
description: The Paleogene Period ended transitioning to the Neogene as grasslands continued expanding, climate continued cooling, and mammals adapted to new open-environment ecological niches.

title: Beginning of Neogene Period
description: The Neogene Period began with grasslands dominating and grazing mammals flourishing. Great apes evolved in Africa, kelp forests appeared, and modern marine ecosystems developed.

title: Beginning of Miocene Epoch
description: The Miocene Epoch began with moderate climates and grassland expansion supporting diverse grazing herds. Apes diversified in Africa and Eurasia, and great white sharks appeared.

title: End of Miocene Epoch
description: The Miocene Epoch ended with climate cooling and drying. Early hominids emerged in Africa as forests fragmented, and the Mediterranean Sea briefly dried up completely.

title: Beginning of Pliocene Epoch
description: The Pliocene Epoch began with continued cooling leading to ice age cycles. Australopithecus and early Homo species evolved in Africa, and the Isthmus of Panama formed.

title: End of Pliocene Epoch
description: The Pliocene Epoch ended as ice ages intensified with glacial cycles establishing. Homo habilis evolved, and many large mammal species migrated between continents via land bridges.

title: End of Neogene Period
description: The Neogene Period ended transitioning into the Quaternary Period characterized by recurring ice ages, human evolution accelerating, and megafauna dominating most continents.

title: Beginning of Quaternary Period
description: The Quaternary Period began with glacial-interglacial cycles dominating. Homo erectus spread worldwide, megafauna thrived, and human ancestors developed stone tools and controlled fire.

title: Beginning of Pleistocene Epoch
description: The Pleistocene Epoch, the Ice Age, began with multiple glacial periods. Mammoths, saber-toothed cats roamed, and Homo sapiens evolved from earlier hominids in Africa.

title: End of Pleistocene Epoch
description: The Pleistocene Epoch ended as the last ice age concluded around 11,700 years ago. Most megafauna went extinct, and humans transitioned from hunter-gatherers to agriculture.

title: Beginning of Holocene Epoch
description: The Holocene Epoch began as glaciers retreated and Earth warmed. Humans developed agriculture, built cities, invented writing, and fundamentally transformed the planet's ecosystems.
